channel.title: NXT (C++) Client
channel.description:
http://imgur.com/a/xoDUq
Set to be released in the second half of the year. There will be a beta, but there is no set date, just in a few months.
You can read more about it [url=http://services.runescape.com/m=forum/forums.ws?198,199,113,65596566]here[/url]

item.title: NXT (C++) Client
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:14, topic:550784”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=669693.msg4478159#msg4478159 date=1427570780]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=669693.msg4478154#msg4478154 date=1427567966]

They say C++ is more cross platform than Java? Is that true?

In the sense of write once run everywhere, no. But it can be targeted to run on everything that Java can.
[/quote]So then it would be “less” cross platform, no? If it’s harder to write cross platform code and it just targets the same machines as Java? They listed the OSs they were targeting and it was ones already working with their Java client… It seems like just a flat out lie to me

A lot of the Java client was done in native code anyways, so theoretically there isn’t that much work to do. As for the cross-platform aspect, its not much harder. There are a few things that are require separate code like WinSock vs BSD sockets, but that has been handled a million times before.
[/quote]I assume you mean the newer clients, because iirc the old"ish" clients had hardly any native code outside of ways to make sure it worked for different file systems and then making sure the libraries for opengl loaded properly[/quote]
Jaggl does a lot more than just make sure OpenGL loaded properly in the newer versions. But according to the article they are redoing the entire back end and porting the rest from the HTML5 client so there’s got to be a fair bit of work involved.

I wonder how long they’ve been working on this and if they can get it shipped before November, or if they’ll force you to use the downloadable client until it is ready.

Read full topic

In the sense of write once run everywhere, no. But it can be targeted to run on everything that Java can.

A lot of the Java client was done in native code anyways, so theoretically there isn’t that much work to do. As for the cross-platform aspect, its not much harder. There are a few things that are require separate code like WinSock vs BSD sockets, but that has been handled a million times before.[/quote]I assume you mean the newer clients, because iirc the old"ish" clients had hardly any native code outside of ways to make sure it worked for different file systems and then making sure the libraries for opengl loaded properly

[quote=“Davidi2, post:12, topic:550784”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=669693.msg4478153#msg4478153 date=1427567408]

They say C++ is more cross platform than Java? Is that true?

In the sense of write once run everywhere, no. But it can be targeted to run on everything that Java can.
[/quote]So then it would be “less” cross platform, no? If it’s harder to write cross platform code and it just targets the same machines as Java? They listed the OSs they were targeting and it was ones already working with their Java client… It seems like just a flat out lie to me[/quote]
A lot of the Java client was done in native code anyways, so theoretically there isn’t that much work to do. As for the cross-platform aspect, its not much harder. There are a few things that are require separate code like WinSock vs BSD sockets, but that has been handled a million times before.

item.title: NXT (C++) Client
item.dc:creator: @Ix_Soulcist_xI Soulcist
item.description:
@Ix_Soulcist_xI wrote:

HcoJustin:

Something OP coined for the next-gen client? Read the article. It says they couldn’t get the performance they wanted out of HTML5 so they are going in a new direction.

Oh right… right, guess it would have helped to looked…

Read full topic

item.title: NXT (C++) Client
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“naseem142, post:6, topic:550784”][quote author=3lv3n snip3r link=topic=669693.msg4478112#msg4478112 date=1427510685]

Java will soon stop being supported by browsers

Please, tell me more.

I may have misread, but here
[/quote]

Even if you misread doesn’t seem that illogical? I mean c’mon…[/quote]
No that is the truth. Come September there will be no support at all in Chrome, and Firefox will be doing the same shortly after.

Soulcist:

Wait, what is NXT? I thought they were doing something with HTML5 or is that the same thing… obviously I have no clue…

Something OP coined for the next-gen client? Read the article. It says they couldn’t get the performance they wanted out of HTML5 so they are going in a new direction.

Read full topic

item.title: NXT (C++) Client
item.dc:creator: @3lv3n_snip3r 3lv3n snip3r
item.description:
@3lv3n_snip3r wrote:

naseem142:

I always thought the game was too bright, but could’nt they just change the lightning rather than this? But either way looks MUCH better!

Since RuneScape is a browser game, and Java will soon stop being supported by browsers, Jagex had to eventually change the client at some point. Also, this new C++ client will supposedly be better, performance, and definitely graphics wise.

Read full topic
